newsitem.title: USA: Indiana soybean seeding hits 93 percent complete.
newsitem.headline: Indiana soybean seeding hits 93 percent complete.

text.p: Soybean seeding in Indiana as of Sunday stood at 93 percent complete, up from 89 percent last week, 43 percent last year and the 82 percent five-year average.
But crop progress remained slow due to continued wet conditions, according to the Indiana Agricultural Statistics Service.
By region, soybean planting was 97 percent complete in the north, 97 percent in the central and 79 percent in the south. Soybeans will need to be replanted in many drowned-out areas.
Corn planting was complete, although replanting was necessary in many areas. Corn condition was rated 52 percent good to excellent, 38 percent fair and 10 percent poor to very poor.

Winter wheat condition was rated 66 percent good to excellent versus 34 percent last year. Statewide, 96 percent of the wheat was headed against 95 percent last year and the average 99 percent. Ripening of the crop has been slowed by cool, wet weather.
Pasture conditions were 12 percent excellent, 57 percent good, 27 percent fair, three percent poor and one percent very poor.
Topsoil moisture was rated 42 percent adequate and 58 percent surplus.
